title: Big banks’ remediation headache moves beyond wealth
text:
Additional unexpected customer compensation related to core banking products such as mortgage rates could dash market hopes that ongoing cost blowouts relating to customer refunds would be put to bed with the pending divestment of the banks’ problematic wealth management subsidiaries.

“The [new ANZ remediation] is significant and disturbing,” said analyst Brett Le Mesurier of Shaw & Partners. “Both the fact that it is taking them so long to work through it and that the numbers are so large.”

Mr Le Mesurier said the sum set aside by ANZ was well beyond his expectations for the half-year, following the more modest allocation of $123 million after tax for the first half of the 2019 financial year.

Commonwealth Bank, National Australia Bank and Westpac are now expected to follow suit with provisions for banking product remediation, as opposed to the more widely anticipated remediation programs for wealth management and financial advisory services, although Mr Le Mesurier said it is unclear whether these bills would be of “similar magnitude to ANZ”.

The fact that NAB and ANZ have employed as many as 500 employees to work full-time on remediation gives no comfort that the remediation programs are almost complete, or that they will be largely confined to wealth management operations, Mr Le Mesurier said.

“Time will tell whether ANZ is now paying the price for being more aggressive with lending practices and fees of the past, or if they have just taken a more conservative approach to fully remediating customers,” said Morningstar analyst Nathan Zaia.

He pointed out that banking product remediation has been ongoing for some time, but that ANZ’s non-wealth compensation was higher than its peers.

CBA made provisions of $182 million for banking remediation in the 2019 financial year, according to Morningstar data.

In March, Westpac attributed “around half” of its $260 million first half 2019 remediation bill to business and consumer banking and the other half to wealth management.

Meanwhile, $832 million of NAB’s recent $1.123 billion half-year remediation allocation related to its financial advice and wealth subsidiaries.

Wealth steals the limelight

Simon Carrodus, solicitor director of The Fold Legal and a former CBA and ASIC lawyer, said banking product remediation programs were longstanding but hade been overshadowed - within the banks and in public perception - by the headline-grabbing wealth management scandals.

“[Banking remediation programs] tended to be considered, by both ASIC and the bank, as less controversial and more of an unfortunate mistake that needed to be rectified, especially in comparison with the more egregious ‘fees for no service’ conduct that was highlighted by ASIC and the [Hayne] royal commission,” he told The Australian Financial Review.

“I would bet that the wealth management remediation is still a bigger focus in the wake of the [royal commission] final report. Even a big bank has limited resources, so they need to prioritise. The issues highlighted by the royal commission are going to be a high priority."

Mr Carrodus added that wealth management customer remediation had been hastened by the banks’ plans to divest from wealth management and make the assets more attractive to prospective purchases.

The big four banks are in varying stages of offloading their wealth management subsidiaries. ANZ has already sold its financial advice dealer group businesses to IOOF and is awaiting board and regulatory approval for the completion of the $1 billion pensions and investments deal.

CBA, Westpac and NAB have announced their intentions to sell the Colonial First State, BT Financial Group and MLC wealth brands respectively, but have not provided clarity on the terms of the divestments.
description: Analysts are bracing for further customer compensation surprises in the wake of ANZ’s fresh $651 million bill.
